description: Borrowed from French cajoler, probably a blend of Middle French cageoler (“chatter like a jay”) (from gajole, dialectal diminutive of geai (“jaybird”)) + Old French gaioler (“entice into a cage”), which is from Medieval Latin gabiola, from Late Latin caveola (whence English caveola), diminutive of Latin cavea (“cage, coop, enclosure, stall”). More at cage, cave, cavum and cavus.

verbs.description: cajole (third-person singular simple present cajoles, present participle cajoling, simple past and past participle cajoled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To persuade someone to do something which they are reluctant to do, especially by flattery or promises; to coax.
examples: Synonyms: butter up, coax, entice, inveigle, sweet-talk, wheedle
